answer_html: \((g \circ f)(a')=g(f(a'))\) we can say that the element f(a’), which is an element of the set B is the element b that we are looking for since it is mapped by g to the element a as requested. This explains why g is surjective.
answer_latex:
$(g \circ f)(a')=g(f(a'))$  we can say that the element \emph{f(a')},
which is an element of the set \emph{B} is the element \emph{b} that we
are looking for since it is mapped by \emph{g} to the element \emph{a}
as requested. This explains why \emph{g} is surjective.
hints_html: A function \(f: C \to D\) is surjective if the function hits all the elements of the arrival set D, that is if for any element d in the set D there is at least one element c in the set C such that f(c)=d.
hints_latex:
A function $f: C \to D$ is \emph{surjective} if the function hits all
the elements of the arrival set \emph{D}, that is if for any element
\emph{d} in the set \emph{D} there is at least one element \emph{c} in
the set \emph{C} such that \emph{f(c)=d}.
hints_raw: A function <math>f: C \to D</math> is ''surjective'' if the function hits all the elements of the arrival set ''D'', that is if for any element ''d'' in the set ''D'' there is at least one element ''c'' in the set ''C'' such that ''f(c)=d''.
question: 9 (a)
sols_html:
We are told that the function \(g \circ f\) is surjective and we want to show that the function \(g\) is surjective as well. For this, let us consider an element in the image of \(g\), that is an element a in the set A (since \(g\) sends elements from B to elements in A).

To show the surjectivity we need to show that there is at least one element b in the set B which is mapped to a by the function g. Now the function \(g \circ f\) sends elements of the set A to the set A and is surjective. So there must exist an element”a”’ in the set A such that

\[\begin{aligned} (g \circ f)(a')=a\end{aligned}\]

But since

\[\begin{aligned} (g \circ f)(a')=g(f(a'))\end{aligned}\]

we can say that the element f(a’), which is an element of the set B is the element b that we are looking for since it is mapped by g to the element a as requested. This explains why g is surjective.
sols_latex:
We are told that the function $g \circ f$~is surjective and we want to
show that the function $g$ is surjective as well. For this, let us
consider an element in the image of $g$, that is an element \emph{a} in
the set \emph{A} (since $g$ sends elements from \emph{B} to elements in
\emph{A}).

To show the surjectivity we need to show that there is at least one
element \emph{b} in the set \emph{B} which is mapped to \emph{a} by the
function \emph{g}. Now the function $g \circ f$ sends elements of the
set \emph{A} to the set \emph{A} and is surjective. So there must exist
an element''a''' in the set \emph{A} such that

\begin{align*}
(g \circ f)(a')=a
\end{align*} But since

\begin{align*}
(g \circ f)(a')=g(f(a'))
\end{align*} we can say that the element \emph{f(a')},
which is an element of the set \emph{B} is the element \emph{b} that we
are looking for since it is mapped by \emph{g} to the element \emph{a}
as requested. This explains why \emph{g} is surjective.
sols_raw:
We are told that the function <math>g \circ f</math> is surjective and we want to show that the function <math>g</math> is surjective as well. For this, let us consider an element in the image of <math>g</math>, that is an element ''a'' in the set ''A'' (since <math>g</math> sends elements from ''B'' to elements in ''A'').

To show the surjectivity we need to show that there is at least one element ''b'' in the set ''B'' which is mapped to ''a'' by the function ''g''. Now the function <math>g \circ f</math> sends elements of the set ''A'' to the set ''A'' and is surjective. So there must exist an element ''a' '' in the set ''A'' such that
:<math>(g \circ f)(a')=a</math>
But since
:<math>(g \circ f)(a')=g(f(a'))</math>
we can say that the element ''f(a')'', which is an element of the set ''B'' is the element ''b'' that we are looking for since it is mapped by ''g'' to the element ''a'' as requested. This explains why ''g'' is surjective.
statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f: A \to B \quad\text{ and }\quad g: B \to A\end{aligned}\]

be functions so that g â—‹f is a surjective function.

Prove that g is surjective.
statement_raw:
Let

:<math>\displaystyle f: A \to B \quad\text{  and  }\quad g: B \to A</math>

be functions so that ''g'' ○''f'' is a surjective function.

Prove that ''g'' is surjective.
